segment.source: Creating a Custom Compatibility Fix in Compatibility Administrator (Windows 10)
segment.target: Creating a Custom Compatibility Fix in Compatibility Administrator (Windows 10)

segment.source: The Compatibility Administrator tool uses the term fix to describe the combination of compatibility information added to a customized database for a specific application.
segment.target: The Compatibility Administrator tool uses the term fix to describe the combination of compatibility information added to a customized database for a specific application.

segment.source: Creating a Custom Compatibility Fix in Compatibility Administrator
segment.target: Creating a Custom Compatibility Fix in Compatibility Administrator

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows 8.1
segment.target: Windows 8.1

segment.source: Windows 8
segment.target: Windows 8

segment.source: Windows 7
segment.target: Windows 7

segment.source: Windows Server 2012
segment.target: Windows Server 2012

segment.source: Windows Server 2008 R2
segment.target: Windows Server 2008 R2

segment.source: The Compatibility Administrator tool uses the term fix to describe the combination of compatibility information added to a customized database for a specific application.
segment.target: The Compatibility Administrator tool uses the term fix to describe the combination of compatibility information added to a customized database for a specific application.

segment.source: This combination can include single application fixes, groups of fixes that work together as a compatibility mode, and blocking and non-blocking AppHelp messages.
segment.target: This combination can include single application fixes, groups of fixes that work together as a compatibility mode, and blocking and non-blocking AppHelp messages.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Fixes apply to a single application only; therefore, you must create multiple fixes if you need to fix the same issue in multiple applications.
segment.target: Fixes apply to a single application only; therefore, you must create multiple fixes if you need to fix the same issue in multiple applications.

segment.source: What is a Compatibility Fix?
segment.target: What is a Compatibility Fix?

segment.source: A compatibility fix, previously known as a shim, is a small piece of code that intercepts API calls from applications.
segment.target: A compatibility fix, previously known as a shim, is a small piece of code that intercepts API calls from applications.

segment.source: The fix transforms the API calls so that the current version of the operating system supports the application in the same way as previous versions of the operating system.
segment.target: The fix transforms the API calls so that the current version of the operating system supports the application in the same way as previous versions of the operating system.

segment.source: This can mean anything from disabling a new feature in the current version of the operating system to emulating a particular behavior of an older version of the Windows API.
segment.target: This can mean anything from disabling a new feature in the current version of the operating system to emulating a particular behavior of an older version of the Windows API.

segment.source: Searching for Existing Compatibility Fixes
segment.target: Searching for Existing Compatibility Fixes

segment.source: The Compatibility Administrator tool has preloaded fixes for many common applications, including known compatibility fixes, compatibility modes, and AppHelp messages.
segment.target: The Compatibility Administrator tool has preloaded fixes for many common applications, including known compatibility fixes, compatibility modes, and AppHelp messages.

segment.source: Before you create a new compatibility fix, you can search for an existing application and then copy and paste the known fixes into your customized database.
segment.target: Before you create a new compatibility fix, you can search for an existing application and then copy and paste the known fixes into your customized database.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Application Compatibility Toolkit (ACT) installs a 32-bit and a 64-bit version of the Compatibility Administrator tool.
segment.target: Application Compatibility Toolkit (ACT) installs a 32-bit and a 64-bit version of the Compatibility Administrator tool.

segment.source: You must use the 32-bit version to create custom databases for 32-bit applications and the 64-bit version to create custom databases for 64-bit applications.
segment.target: You must use the 32-bit version to create custom databases for 32-bit applications and the 64-bit version to create custom databases for 64-bit applications.

segment.source: To search for an existing application
segment.target: To search for an existing application

segment.source: In the left-side pane of Compatibility Administrator, expand the Applications folder and search for your application name.
segment.target: In the left-side pane of Compatibility Administrator, expand the Applications folder and search for your application name.

segment.source: Click the application name to view the preloaded compatibility fixes, compatibility modes, or AppHelp messages.
segment.target: Click the application name to view the preloaded compatibility fixes, compatibility modes, or AppHelp messages.

segment.source: Creating a New Compatibility Fix
segment.target: Creating a New Compatibility Fix

segment.source: If you are unable to find a preloaded compatibility fix for your application, you can create a new one for use by your customized database.
segment.target: If you are unable to find a preloaded compatibility fix for your application, you can create a new one for use by your customized database.

segment.source: To create a new compatibility fix
segment.target: To create a new compatibility fix

segment.source: In the left-side pane of Compatibility Administrator underneath the Custom Databases heading, right-click the name of the database to which you want to apply the compatibility fix, click Create New, and then click Application Fix.
segment.target: In the left-side pane of Compatibility Administrator underneath the Custom Databases heading, right-click the name of the database to which you want to apply the compatibility fix, click Create New, and then click Application Fix.

segment.source: Type the name of the application to which the compatibility fix applies, type the name of the application vendor, browse to the location of the application file (.exe) on your computer, and then click Next.
segment.target: Type the name of the application to which the compatibility fix applies, type the name of the application vendor, browse to the location of the application file (.exe) on your computer, and then click Next.

segment.source: Select the operating system for which your compatibility fix applies, click any applicable compatibility modes to apply to your compatibility fix, and then click Next.
segment.target: Select the operating system for which your compatibility fix applies, click any applicable compatibility modes to apply to your compatibility fix, and then click Next.

segment.source: Select any additional compatibility fixes to apply to your compatibility fix, and then click Next.
segment.target: Select any additional compatibility fixes to apply to your compatibility fix, and then click Next.

segment.source: Select any additional criteria to use to match your applications to the AppHelp message, and then click Finish.
segment.target: Select any additional criteria to use to match your applications to the AppHelp message, and then click Finish.

segment.source: By default, Compatibility Administrator selects the basic matching criteria for your application.
segment.target: By default, Compatibility Administrator selects the basic matching criteria for your application.

segment.source: As a best practice, use a limited set of matching information to represent your application, because it reduces the size of the database.
segment.target: As a best practice, use a limited set of matching information to represent your application, because it reduces the size of the database.

segment.source: However, make sure you have enough information to correctly identify your application.
segment.target: However, make sure you have enough information to correctly identify your application.
